note: Hosted campaign themed event. On October 2nd 2018 we held our EGM (extraordinary general meeting), an event we host every October in our college. At this event we outlined our plans for the year ahead, and sought feedback from students. At the EGM we held elections for members to join our committee. We elected 9 new members to our committee who all confirmed they support the mission of SSDP to see reform to Drug Policy. Furthermore our new members expressed passion in seeing our harm-reduction campaign for the year ahead come to fruition. We have now publicly committed to a rigorous year of promoting harm-reduction policies for the year ahead. Also mentioned at the EGM by our Chairperson was that next year (April-May 2019) we will engage with local city and county councillors to adopt a pro-harm reduction stance when running for council elections which are set to take place in Summer 2019. Facebook link to our event - https://www.facebook.com/events/2175798829298372/

note: The Irish government has recently announced that they will be implementing supervised injection facilities in Ireland, with the first center to be piloted in Dublin. The project will be supervised by our national health service (known as the 'HSE'). SSDP chapters in Ireland have long been involved in different lobbying movements to see this happen. UCC SSDP and CIT SSDP (chapters based in County Cork, ROI) will continue to lobby to see this expanded from state level to local level.
title: Policy changed or adopted (50 points)

note: Earlier this year our SSDP chapter saw our motion passed in our colleges Student Council, which called for our Student Union to lobby our college to provide an affordable drug testing kit program to students and implement better harm reduction education (Link to news article regarding that motion passing: https://www.eveningecho.ie/corknews/UCC-Students-Union-vote-to-introduce-drug-checking-kits-cfa49e32-49d1-4286-8e25-710a4f38f6b1-ds). Earlier this week (Monday Nov. 19th), David, Adam and Ruby from our chapter met with 2 representatives of our Students Union to discuss what had been done since the motion passed and what needs to be done moving forward. The Harm Reduction education has proved successful, with every freshers park first year received this August (start of semester) containing harm reduction leaflets and cards we approve of. Our SU have adopted a more harm reduction based approach to any drug related issues. We are helping them in their campaign to see testing-kits be provided with students right now.
